Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Teams: Photonic Crystal Enabled Thermophotovoltaic Portable Power Generator
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to enable a new portable power source with unprecedented energy density, which could have transformative effects on military and commercial portable/autonomous systems. For example, a portable power generator for soldiers using the proposed technology would result in a 50-75% weight reduction on a 72-hour mission, meaning soldiers could bring more water and ammo or reduce chance of injury due to weight. The proposed technology could also extend the operation of drones and other unmanned vehicles on land, air, and water. Currently these applications are almost exclusively powered by batteries, despite hydrocarbon fuel being 60 times more energy dense. The proposed technology could also be used in a number of commercial applications from emergency response and disaster relief, remote sensing, and energy access in emerging markets.

This I-Corps project is a new approach to thermophotovoltaics, using a photonic crystal selective emitter, that enables practical fuel to electricity conversion in the 1-100 W range. The technology works by converting fuel to electricity using heat and light as intermediaries. Specifically, hydrocarbon combustion heats a photonic crystal emitter to incandescence, leading to thermal radiation which drives specialized photovoltaic cells to generate electricity. Currently, there is no effective power source for applications requiring 1-100 Watts of electricity for extended duration, a space where demand is burgeoning. This technology would enable ultraportable, reliable, and silent energy generation, particularly for applications that do not have access to conventional power sources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the period of performance, we conducted an intensive customer discovery and interview process accomplishing over 250 interviews with potential end users and customers. Product market fit was established in several industries.

Coming from the Institute for Soldier Nanotechnologies at MIT, our initial interviews focused on dismounted Soldiers on multi-day missions. We found that a real need exists for warfighters on the battlefield deployed on extended duration missions to reduce their battery load and increase their capability. One of their biggest pains is to carry multiple sets of large heavy batteries to power all their communications equipment. We found that reliability and silent operation are key which is why batteries have been so prevalent, but we also learned that battery resupply is costly and in many cases difficult.

In parallel, we investigated the remote instrumentation market. We discovered that in remote areas without access to electrical grid, running a transmission line is very expensive, solar and wind resources are unreliable, and the available solutions are typically large permanent installations. In Antarctica, researchers need to power their remote instrumentation for years at a time, without access to reliable power or even sunlight. In the oil and gas industry, managers of remote wellpads and remote pipelines want to improve the reliability of their installations. Remote communities and disaster relief personnel often do not have access to reliable power.

Investigating the remote instrumentation market on land lead us to remote instrumentation in the ocean. We learned that hundreds of thousands of unmanned remote sensors have been deployed in the oceans and along the coast. Collecting this data from the ocean has been difficult and expensive due to the remoteness and extreme conditions. Recent advances in the quality and proliferation of unmanned systems and sensors has made it easier than ever and more cost effective to continuously gather data, using unmanned surface vessels (USVs) for example. However, these systems depend on the reliability of the sources that are powering them.

Finally, investigating maritime USVs lead us to the small unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) market. Specifically, in the drone industry, we found great product market fit with manufacturers of small Group 1 and 2 UAVs (<55 pounds) who want to extend the range and endurance of their drone beyond what is currently possible with available battery technologies. We found that the key pain points today for these manufacturers are endurance and reliability. Batteries are reliable but short endurance. Small internal combustion engines have long endurance but low reliability. Fuel cells have emerged as a promising technology but require specialized fuel and pressurized vessels which are heavy. 

Drones are revolutionizing many industries from package delivery to infrastructure inspection, fire prevention, and more. Mesodyne?s patented generator would enable unprecedented new capabilities and cost saving for drone manufacturers: ability to fly up to ten times further than with batteries alone; improved reliability over internal combustion engines with no vibration; liquid-fuel operation with minimal overhead; and small lightweight form factor to maximize payload capability. This combination of attributes defines a new category of power generation capability.

The broader impact of Mesodyne's technology is that our power generator is a platform technology benefiting all applications where performance is limited by battery weight or where all other sources of power (grid, solar, wind, etc.) are not available or practical - enabling compact, reliable, long endurance, power generation from any fuel source.
